comments.author: Andrew Menteer

comments.text:
I gotta say, I was a little upset at the chevy swap. Although its probably 
a great swap it seems like thats all they do for engines on this show. Now 
they've hacked the firewall all up to make the chevy v8 fit when the jeep 
was already set up for a ford big block when they got it. I personally 
think a rebuilt big block would have been way cooler, less destructive and 
at least semi period correct.﻿

comments.text: idiots﻿
comments.author: Jason Elliot

comments.text:
That brings back memories, both good and bad: I owned a very similar 1958 
willis wagon for a number of years some fourty years ago.  It was mostly 
original w/ the heavy cast iron flat head four engine and 3 speed crash box 
drive train.  Those wagons are a great size, good visibility and a classic 
look, what is not to like?  I normally hate the idea of altering a classic, 
but yours was already butchered, if it were me, to make it a good boondocks 
traveler, I would replace just about every mechanical system: install a 
much lighter (and more reliable) Toyota all aluminum EFI V-6 and a manual 
trans and drive train; than junk the useless suicide drum brakes and 
install modern power disks, and use the Toyota power steering system as 
well.  dump the heavy and sloppy leaf spring suspension for a 4 bar,/coil 
spring suspension (it will lower the risk of a roll over, and improve the 
ride and handling considerably).  round out with good modern bucket seats 
with seat belts, full instrument cluster, insulation and new interior 
finish, halogen head lights; and than you will have a lighter, safer, more 
reliable and comfortable outback rig. I learned by experiance (thanks to 
that sloppy leaf spring suspension) that the Willis wagon body is strong 
enough to take a full roll over without any reinforcement (and remarkably 
little damage), so a roll cage should not be necessary for anything but off 
road racing.  though the chassis frame could reinforced for good handling 
and durability.  Get a wrecked Toyota Tacoma at an auction for your source 
of parts.  Toyota parts are very well made, plentiful and cheap, and darn 
reliable. The perfect way to modernize an old classic.﻿
